publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l:
────Fragili quærens illidere denten
Offendet Solido────
ADmire not Sir, that I so Long un-seen,
Have but in Secret thy Attendant been:
That Tortur'd long I never dar'd, till now,
My Hate of thee before the World avow
Still had I hid my Fury in my Breast,
Would my relentless Snakes but let me rest.
For long I've learn'd my Lot ordain'd by Fate,
To raise those Names most high, whom most I hate.
But oh in vain I strove, the eating Flame
Would out, tho well I knew it seal'd thy Fame.
You may rejoyce; your Glory is secure,
And it must now with time it self endure.
Fam'd Homer, Maro, Dryden, had from me,
No greater Favours than I've shown to thee.
No greater Rage against them I display'd,
Nor greater folly in that rage betray'd.
Nor thou, tho dire I seem to weaker Eyes,
Fond Man, the Glory of my Hate despise.
Not all the countless Praises you have gain'd,
From Crouds of Youth by thee to Virtue train'd,
By thee with ev'ry nobler Science grac'd,
Distinguish'd for their Elegance of Tast:
Not all the Crouds that round thy Pulpit throng,
Rapt with the Force of thy persuasive Tongue,
Not all the Wretched by thy Bounty eas'd,
Nor modest Merit by thy Friendship rais'd,
Not all you e'er can do, or preach or write
Exalts your Glory equal to my Spite.
The Orator's Harangue, the Poet's Lays,
Tho' tuning all their Notes to Vertue's Praise,
The breathing Marble, and th' expressive Coin.
Tho' History with them her Labours joyn;
All these, united, can't true Worth declare;
Since oft th' Effects of Flattery or Fear:
True Worth is best determin'd by my Hate:
That cannot be Suspected of Deceit.
